titleStmt.title: Directed Evolution of an FeII-Dependent Halogenase for Asymmetric C(sp3)-H Chlorination

analytic.title: Directed Evolution of an FeII-Dependent Halogenase for Asymmetric C(sp3)-H Chlorination

div.p: By using structure-guided directed evolution, the substrate scope of the Fe II and -ketoglutarate dependent halogenase Wi-WelO15 from Westiella intricata HT-29-1 was engineered to enable chemo-, regio-and diastereoselective chlorination of unactivated C(sp 3 )-H bonds using NaCl as chlorine source. While Fe II dependent enzymes are often oxygen sensitive, variants of this halogenase could be screened in lysates under aerobic conditions. The developed biocatalysts offer a route to mild, late-stage chlorination on mg-scale of non-natural hapalindoles containing a ketone instead of an isonitrile functionality, thereby unlocking them for preparative biocatalysis.

Organochlorines play an important role in medicinal chemistry, agrochemicals, and as synthetic intermediates. [1][2][3] Selective C-H bond functionalization in the absence of directing groups greatly simplifies synthesis 4,5 and enables late-stage diversification of complex molecules. [6][7][8] Chemo-, regio-and stereoselective C-Cl bond formation under mild and non-hazardous conditions is still a formidable challenge in chemical [9][10][11] and enzymatic [12][13][14][15][16] catalysis, especially direct functionalization of unactivated C(sp 3 )-H bonds. 4,8 Nature has evolved highly selective aliphatic halogenases 12- 16 for performing late-stage halogenations of unactivated C(sp 3 )-H bonds via radical intermediates (Figure 1a). 17,18 Remarkably, NaCl is the chlorine source and O2 and -ketoglutarate (KG) activate the catalytic Fe. Two challenges exist with this enzyme class, first, competing pathways of hydroxylation versus halogenation, and second, early characterized members act on substrates covalently bound to a carrier protein. 19,20 Only recently, aliphatic halogenases acting on free-standing molecules were discovered in the biosynthesis of hapalindoles, [21][22][23] a natural product class with a broad range of biological properties from antibacterial, antimycotic to anticancer. 24 Although their molecular mode of action and the exact role of the chloride is unknown, it is truly the late stage chlorination performed by Fe II and KG dependent halogenases that drew our interest from a biocatalytic point-of-view. This reaction was shown for three enzymes from different biosynthetic hapalindole gene clusters, i.e. WelO5, AmbO5, and Hw-WelO15 (Figure 1b). [25][26][27] Due to the novelty of the sequence, homology modeling to predict the active site residues failed until a crystal structures of WelO5 was released. 28,29 By creating chimeras, the natural substrate scope of WelO5 was expanded to that of AmbO5 albeit with reduced activity. 26 However, all natural sub-strates contain an isonitrile functionality, which is a major limitation considering that they are sensitive and rarely to never occur as synthetic intermediates or functional groups in drugs.

Herein, we report the directed evolution of an Fe II and KG dependent halogenase Wi-WelO15 from Westiella intricata HT-29-1 for the mild chemo-, regio-and diastereoselective chlorination of unactivated C(sp 3 )-H bonds of non-natural substrates devoid of any isonitrile functionality and we demonstrate that this enzymatic late-stage C(sp 3 )-H chlorination can be performed on preparative mg-scale (Figure 1c). We initiated our study by synthesizing a simplified derivative of 12-epi-hapalindole C, which is a natural substrate of Fe II /KG dependent halogenases. The vinyl group was replaced by a methyl (1) and, more importantly, the isonitrile group was replaced with a keto moiety (2). These changes simplified the synthesis of screening compound 2 by several steps, while additionally the ketone functionality opens new routes to novel chemical diversification of this alkaloid class.

Initially, we cloned Hw-WelO15 from Hapalosiphon welwitschii IC-52-3 and a new fourth homolog, Wi-WelO15 from Westiella intricata HT-29-1. The two chlorinases have 94 and 99% sequence identity to the characterized WelO5, respectively. Transformation of compound 1 yielded 91-93% chlorinated R-1a with both recombinantly expressed enzymes, Hw-WelO15 and Wi-WelO15, revealing that the vinyl to methyl exchange appears to have little effect on substrate recognition. The isonitrile group was suggested to play a major role in native substrate recognition 28 which we replaced with a carbonyl group in 2, keeping the H-bond acceptor feature. This functional group change abolished the activity of Hw-WelO15 and Wi-WelO15, under our initial reaction conditions, confirming the importance of the isonitrile for substrate binding in the wild type enzymes. By mass spectrometry, we could exclude enzyme inactivation by self-oxidation, a common problem for many related Fe II /KG dependent dioxygenases. 30,31 With the goal to create a collection of engineered enzymes for mild and asymmetric chlorination in organic synthesis, compound 2 was selected as our lead structure. Residues selected for mutagenesis are shown in green (1 st sphere, generation 1-3) and cyan (2 nd sphere, 4 th generation). Grey residues did not yield active variants in the 1 st generation.

To gain structural insight, a wild-type like variant of Wi-WelO15 (Wi-0) was crystallized. 32 Wi-0 differs by two surface mutations from Wi-Wel015, one at each terminus which originate from primer design. This has no effect on activity and expression (Figure S3 and S8). It has to be noted that while our work was in progress, a crystal structure of WeIO5 in complex with 12-epi-fischerindole U was reported. 28,29 The structure of Wi-0 was solved by molecular replacement using WelO5. In comparison to the structure by Liu, Boal and coworkers, the enzymatical lid of Wi-0 is shifted downwards, underlining the flexibility of these enzymes. Using YASARA, 33 compound 2 was docked into the active site of Wi-0 (Figure 2) as well as in the open and closed forms of WelO5. The information obtained by the docking studies was used as starting point for structure guided enzyme evolution. [34][35][36][37][38][39] Next, we implemented an aerobic and lysate-based screening protocol, using 2 as screening substrate, for HPLC screening (see Supporting Information for details), and started a structureguided directed evolution campaign of Wi-0 using strategies reported by Reetz and Bäckvall. [40][41][42] Based on their vicinity to the docked compound 2, seven active site residues were initially selected for single-site saturation mutagenesis (1 st generation, Figure 3). As a result, obtained hits from the HPLC assay showed primarily hydrophobic or small amino acids as new residues. In the 2 nd generation, the active site was reshaped by multi-residue libraries, allowing for cooperative effects. 40,42 Small, targeted, libraries were designed by using reduced amino acid alphabets compiled from the single-site saturation results of generation 1. We used the DC analyzer 43 to reduce codon redundancy. The library sizes (screening effort) 44 were designed using statistical guidance allowing for a 95% chance to find 1 out of the top 3 variants. 45,46 Wi-5 (A82L/V90P) and Wi-7 (V81T/A82M/A88V/ V90P) were identified as the best variants in the 2 nd generation. Meanwhile, we found N74R at the end of the active site tunnel having subtle positive effects on production of 2a. Hence, 1 st and 2 nd generation hits were rationally fine-tuned by adding the mutation N74R, creating the 3 rd generation. Variants showed a broad spectrum of positive and negative effects on the production of 2a, with Wi-8 (N74R/V81T/A82M/A88V/V90P) being the best hit. S5 and S6.

After screening generation 1-3, 12 hits were characterized with optimized reaction conditions as lysates obtained from OD600 normalized cell suspensions (Table S5). Reaction optimization included the substitution of dithiothreitol (DTT) with ascorbic acid for Fe II recycling 47,48 and using higher sodium chloride (100 mM) concentration. We tested screening compound 2 and derivatives 3-5 with substituents introduced into the indole part of the substrate. Under these controlled conditions, Wi-5 and Wi-8 were identified as the most promising variants producing up to 60% of the chlorination products 2a-5a with >99.9% regio-and stereoselectivity.

To further increase activity, Wi-5 and Wi-8 were selected as templates for another round of evolution (4 th generation). Learning from the effect of N74, we selected 2 nd sphere residues N74, S93, S103 and A175 (Figure 2) for a multi-site library and again used tailored reduced alphabets. Screening yielded variant Wi-11 (N74R/V81T/A82M/A88V/ V90P/S93L/S103A) and Wi-12 (N74R/A82L/V90P/S93D) as top variants producing chlorinated 2a.

Next, we verified the catalytic activities of the obtained hits with isolated and purified variants. Selected chlorinases were tested with compounds 1-8. First, we decided to probe the impact of the isonitrile/ketone substitution. As a result, the engineered Wi-WelO15 variants still chlorinate the isonitrile 1 with an expected reduced efficiency (Table S6). Under optimized reaction conditions, Wi-0 hardly transformed the ketones 2-5 (<1% yields), whereas Hw-WelO15 produced moderate amounts of chlorinated ketones 2a-5a, with 3 being the best substrate obtaining 3a in 33% yield. All natural hapalindoles contain either isonitriles or isothiocyanates, but our work demonstrates that some of the wild types, i.e. Hw-WelO15, might be more versatile than anticipated.

Using 2 mol% purified Wi-11 or Wi-12, 91% of 2a was obtained (Figure 4). When exploring the tolerance of indole ring substitutions, we found that the simple methylation at C5 or C6 reduced chlorination to 14% or 26% production at the best for 3a or 5a with purified variants Wi-5 and Wi-11, respectively. It is often recognized that certain enzymes/processes work better in lysate than as purified enzymes, benefiting from the presence of various cell components. Using lysates instead, containing a comparable amount of catalyst, production improved to 34% (3a) and 50% (5a) Wi-4 and Wi-8. Highest product formation from either purified enzyme or cell lysate reactions is given in Figure 4.

Introducing the H-bond acceptor OMe at C5 recovered activity giving 42% 4a with purified Wi-5 and 54% with lysate of Wi-8. Products were found to be chlorinated on C13 with Rconfiguration, showing identical absolute stereochemistry as related 12-epi-hapalindole E. In summary, our chlorinase panel allows late-stage chlorination and access to 1a-5a with regioand diastereoselectivities >99.9%.

Small structural changes in the terpene ring of 6-8 proved to be more challenging. Elimination of a methyl group at C12 (6) or sp 2 hybridization (8) abolished detectable chlorination, deducing that C12 position requires a quaternary carbon center for corrected substrate positioning prior to chlorination. Nevertheless, substrates 6-8 are transformed with moderate activity into several new products. LC-MS analysis assigned most of them to be hydroxylated compounds. Hydroxylation was not observed during screening, but the higher activities under optimized reaction conditions revealed minor hydroxylation of 2-5, too. Yet, our panel allows chlorination of 2-5 with excellent chemoselectivities of 96-99% (Tables S5 and S6). Achieving such a high selectivity is exceptional because non-natural substrates for Fe II /KG dependent halogenases are predominantly reported to be hydroxylated. 49,50 Interestingly, despite their low activity, Hw-WelO15 wild type and Wi-WelO15 variants carrying I84H start shifting chemoselectivity towards 30% hydroxylation of 2 (Figure S16), an indication that chemoselectivity can also be controlled solely by substrate binding site mutations. S5 and S6) for 8 h and 30 °C in 200 µL with 0.5 mM 1-8 with either [a] 2 mol% (10 µM) purified enzyme or [b] cell lysate (prior to lysis normalized to OD600 = 5.0). Absolute stereoconformation was assigned by NOESY and crystal structures of 1-3 (CCDC 1839575-1839577). A detailed overview is provided in Tables S5 and S6. [c] Yield after HPLC purification. [d] Total conversion, <1% chlorination. Chemical synthesis of chlorinated hapalindoles and their ketone precursors involve early-stage chlorination. [51][52][53] In sharp contrast, using lysates of our Wi-5 variant, we here demonstrated late-stage chlorination of 2-5 on mg-scale in a single step, producing 4.5 to 8.5 mg (7-48% yield) after HPLC purification of the new hapalindole derivatives. This late-stage chlorination opens new synthetic routes to structurally diverse chlorinated hapalindoles and will accelerate their exploration in pharmacology.

Finally, kinetics for the chlorination of 2 were performed (Table 1). The 4 th generation variants Wi-11 and Wi-12 show the best vmax, with a 131 to 276-fold improvement compared to Wi-1. The mutations affect turnover and binding differently. Despite having a similar catalytic efficiency, Wi-11 is the fastest, but Wi-12 binds compound 2 more strongly. Variant Wi-5, which proved to be a valuable variant for scale up (Table S7), was found to show highest catalytic efficiency with 2. The kinetic data reveals that our evolved chlorinases are as efficient biocatalysts for preparative synthesis as the engineered and mechanistically related oxygenase TauD 54 and the engineered flavin dependent halogenases PrnA 55 and RebH 56 with non-natural substrates.
Table 1. Selected kinetics for the chlorination of 2 with Wi-WelO15 variants.
Enzyme [a] vmax /µM min -1 Km /µM

In conclusion, the power of structure-guided directed evolution was demonstrated by evolving a member of the challenging class of Fe II /KG dependent chlorinases. It was possible to exchange the isonitrile, present in natural substrates, by a common carbonyl group. This mild, late-stage chlorination using NaCl as halogen source provides the unique possibility to functionalize unactivated, aliphatic C(sp 3 )-H bonds in the presence of more electron-rich functional groups, which is a remaining challenge in today's synthesis toolbox. 4,8 We also demonstrated that our WelO15 variant panel can be used for late-stage chlorination on mg-scale with perfect regio-and stereoselectivity (>99.9%) and excellent chemoselectivity (96-99%) under mild reaction conditions. With our findings, further engineering projects can be pursued towards substrates that have broader purposes. While this manuscript was under review, Hayashi et al. 57 demonstrated comparable evolutionary success with a martinelline-derived fragment, and Neugebauer et al. 58 identified a new family member acting on amino acids. Hayashi et al. 57 confirmed the importance of V81, A82 and A88 for the adaptation of this enzyme class towards non-natural substrates. Their and our residues might be considered as an important starting point for future engineering studies to improve the turnover number and binding constant of new non-natural substrates. We expect that structural investigations with our variants will reveal the ketone binding mode and ultimately lead to a deeper insight into the structure-function relationship for this enzyme class.

figure.head: Figure 1 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 1. (a) Asymmetric chlorination of unactivated C-(sp 3 )-H bonds by Fe II /KG dependent halogenases. (b) Natural substrates studied by Liu and coworkers, which all contain isonitrile functionalities. (c) Non-natural substrates derived from the structure of 12epi-hapalindole C. Positions of chlorination are highlighted.

figure.head: Figure 2 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 2. Lead structure 2 (yellow) docked in the open conformation of Wi-0. Residues selected for mutagenesis are shown in green (1 st sphere, generation 1-3) and cyan (2 nd sphere, 4 th generation). Grey residues did not yield active variants in the 1 st generation.

figure.head: Figure 3 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 3. Engineering workflow of the halogenase Wi-WelO15. Screening effort given in brackets. Activity and selectivity information is provided in TablesS5 and S6.

figure.head: Figure 4 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 4. Substrate scope of Wi-WelO15 variants. Highest product formation (% HPLC) is given, comparing purified enzyme and cell lysate (TableS5 and S6) for 8 h and 30 °C in 200 µL with 0.5 mM 1-8 with either [a] 2 mol% (10 µM) purified enzyme or [b] cell lysate (prior to lysis normalized to OD600 = 5.0). Absolute stereoconformation was assigned by NOESY and crystal structures of 1-3 (CCDC 1839575-1839577). A detailed overview is provided in TablesS5 and S6. [c] Yield after HPLC purification. [d] Total conversion, <1% chlorination.

div.head: ACKNOWLEDGMENT
div.p: We thank the LOEWE Research Cluster SynChemBio and Philipps-Universität Marburg for funding, M. Moffit for genomic DNA, R. Viswanathan for fruitful discussions and compounds, M. T. Reetz for access to instruments, and the mass/NMR dep./E. Winterling for excellent technical assistance. We also thank the DFG for co-financing SynaptG2Si (INST 160/621-1 FUGG to U. Linne/ G. Bange) and AccuTOF GCv 4G (JEOL) (INST 160/622-1 FUGG to U. Linne), beamline staff at ID23-2, European Synchrotron Radiation Facility (ESRF), Grenoble, France for support during data collection.

monogr.title: Wi-0 nor Hw-WelO15 showed activity with compound 2 and only Wi-0 crystallized. kcat and Km

biblStruct.note: In initial tests Wi-0 with 1 are in the same range as reported values of WelO5. (details see SI

In initial tests, neither Wi-0 nor Hw-WelO15 showed activity with compound 2 and only Wi-0 crystallized. kcat and Km (Wi-0, 1, 1.44 min -1 , 17.2 µM) of Wi- 0 with 1 are in the same range as reported values of WelO5. (details see SI).

monogr.title: Enzyme engineer always face the challenge to balance numbers of residues, used amino acids alphabets and codon redundancy to avoid the combinatorial number explosion problem during library design. Our HPLC could handle a maximum of 10-12 96-deep

biblStruct.note: well plates per library as an upper limit

Enzyme engineer always face the challenge to balance numbers of residues, used amino acids alphabets and codon redundancy to avoid the combinatorial num- ber explosion problem during library design. Our HPLC could handle a maxi- mum of 10-12 96-deep-well plates per library as an upper limit.
